channel.title: User Interfaces
channel.description:
Hello, I am currently trying to create a user interface framework. It's not going to be anything really serious, just one of my many projects. I know how to use AWT/Swing, and I've created a pseudo-framework already (simple component library, event handling) that makes use of the paint(Graphics) method(obviously...). It was pretty nice when I finished it. It didn't have anything like shading or complex things like that. Just a simple little framework.
Anyways, I'm currently creating new operating systems for small devices (currently N64, and gameboy pocket) and I would like to have something more... robust than just a CLI menu (just using basic vga features, set the foreground to (0, 0, 0), etc). I'm most comfortable with Java, and since it's platform independent, I figured I'd try it out with that first. My previous framework was built on top of Frames/Windows and Canvases. I'd like to remove this dependency. So how would I got about doing this? Would I have to create a whole new graphics engine, or would I pretty much just have to write some native code, and bind the java to that with the JNI?
tl;dr: want to create independent user interface framework and don't know where to start.

item.title: User Interfaces
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Unhandled:

since when can you run java on an n64 or gameboy?

Like I said, I worded things strangely last night. For the N64 and Gameboy, I made a pseudo UI framework. All it is now is a text-based menu. The D-Pad moves the selection up and down, A goes to the sub menu if any, B goes to the previous etc. I would like to create something more robust, and with more components(buttons, checkboxes, etc). I thought it would be easier to create something like this with Java since I don’t have to mess with the hardware at all, and once I get it organized the way I want, the “port” it to whatever device I want.
